title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Important Concepts



Random Sample


A sample of size \(n\), drawn from a population according to a random process, is called a random sample if the values of the random variables \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) are independent and identically distributed.

\(X_1\) denotes the first element of the sample
\(X_2\) denotes the second element
\(X_n\) denotes the \(n\)-th element

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Parameters and Statistics



Parameter


A parameter is a value that characterizes a given population which, although unknown, is fixed.
Examples: population mean \(\mu\), population variance \(\sigma^2\)







Statistic


A statistic is a characteristic that is a function of the sample values; that is, it‚Äôs a random variable that does not involve any unknown parameters. If the statistic is used to estimate a parameter, then this statistic is called an estimator.
Symbolized by: \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example: What is a Statistic?
Consider a random sample \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\), \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), from a population \(X \sim Normal(\mu = -2, \sigma^2)\), where \(\sigma^2\) is unknown.
Which of the following are statistics?

\(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n\)
\(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \frac{X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n}{n} = \bar{X}\)
\(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \frac{\bar{X}}{\sigma}\)
\(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example: Solution

a) YES - Sum of sample values (no unknown parameters)
b) YES - Sample mean (no unknown parameters)
c) NO - Contains \(\sigma\) which is unknown
d) NO - Contains both \(\mu\) (known = -2, so this part is OK) and \(\sigma\) (unknown)


Note: For it to be a statistic, we must be able to calculate it from the sample data alone, without knowledge of unknown population parameters.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Properties of t-Student
Key Properties:

Symmetric around zero: \(E[T] = 0\) (for \(\nu > 1\))
Variance: \(Var[T] = \frac{\nu}{\nu - 2}\) (for \(\nu > 2\))
As \(\nu \to \infty\): \(t_\nu \to N(0,1)\)
Heavier tails than the standard normal distribution
Shape depends on degrees of freedom \(\nu\)

The t-distribution (red) has heavier tails than the Normal (dashed). As \(\nu\) increases, it approaches the Normal distribution.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Using t-Student Tables
For a t-Student distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom:

Tables typically provide: \(P(T > t_{\alpha, \nu}) = \alpha\)
Due to symmetry: \(t_{1-\alpha, \nu} = -t_{\alpha, \nu}\)


Example: For \(\nu = 10\) and \(\alpha = 0.05\):

\(t_{0.05, 10} = 1.812\)
This means: \(P(T > 1.812) = 0.05\)
By symmetry: \(P(T < -1.812) = 0.05\)

Properties of Chi-square
Key Properties:

\(E[Y] = \nu\) (mean equals degrees of freedom)
\(V[Y] = 2\nu\)
Right-skewed distribution (not symmetric)
Only positive values
Sum property: If \(Q_1 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_1}\) and \(Q_2 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_2}\) are independent, then \(Q_1 + Q_2 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_1 + \nu_2}\)

title: Sampling Distributions

Using Chi-square Tables
For a chi-square distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom:

Tables provide: \(P(Q > \chi^2_{\alpha, \nu}) = \alpha\)
Important: Not symmetric, so \(\chi^2_{1-\alpha, \nu} \neq -\chi^2_{\alpha, \nu}\)

Example: For \(\nu = 10\):

\(\chi^2_{0.05, 10} = 18.307\) means \(P(Q > 18.307) = 0.05\)
\(\chi^2_{0.95, 10} = 3.940\) means \(P(Q > 3.940) = 0.95\)

Case 1: Normal Population, \(\sigma\) Known

Setup:

Population: \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma)\) with \(\sigma^2\) known
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) where \(X_i \sim N(\mu, \sigma)\)
Statistic: Sample mean \(\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Case 2: Normal Population, \(\sigma\) Unknown

Setup:

Population: \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma)\) with \(\sigma^2\) unknown
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\)
Statistic: Sample mean \(\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Important Note






When to Use t vs.¬†Z



It‚Äôs rare to know \(\sigma^2\) without knowing \(\mu\)
In practice, we almost always use the t-Student distribution
We estimate \(\sigma\) using the sample standard deviation \(S\) or \(S'\)
The t-distribution accounts for the uncertainty from estimating \(\sigma\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Case 3: Unknown Population, Large Sample

Setup:

Population: Unknown distribution with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\) known
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) with \(n \geq 30\)
Statistic: Sample mean \(\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Central Limit Theorem (CLT)



Central Limit Theorem


Regardless of the population distribution, as the sample size \(n\) increases, the sampling distribution of \(\bar{X}\) approaches a Normal distribution with:

Mean: \(E[\bar{X}] = \mu\)
Standard Deviation: \(\sqrt{V[\bar{X}]} = \sigma/\sqrt{n}\)

This is one of the most important theorems in statistics!

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Case 3 (Continued): \(\sigma\) Unknown, Large Sample
When \(\sigma\) is unknown and \(n > 30\):
\[Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{S/(n-1)^{1/2}} = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{S'/\sqrt{n}} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N(0, 1)\]

The t-distribution with many degrees of freedom is approximately Normal
For practical purposes, \(t_{n-1} \approx N(0,1)\) when \(n > 30\)

title: Sampling Distributions

Distribution of Sample Variance

Setup:

Population: \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma)\) with \(\mu\) unknown and variance \(\sigma^2\)
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\) where \(X_i \sim N(\mu, \sigma)\)
Statistics:

Sample variance: \(S^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2\)
Corrected sample variance: \(S'^2 = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2 = \frac{n}{n-1}S^2\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Sampling Distribution of Variance
Result:
\[Q = \frac{(n-1)S'^2}{\sigma^2} = \frac{nS^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{n-1}\]






Note



The chi-square distribution has \(n-1\) degrees of freedom
We lose one degree of freedom because we estimate \(\mu\) with \(\bar{X}\)
This result is only exact for Normal populations

title: Sampling Distributions
section: Why Do We Lose a Degree of Freedom?
text:
Why Do We Lose a Degree of Freedom?
When calculating \(S^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2\):

We have \(n\) observations: \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\)
But we use \(\bar{X}\) (calculated from the data) instead of \(\mu\)
The \(n\) deviations \((X_i - \bar{X})\) must sum to zero
Therefore, only \(n-1\) of them are ‚Äúfree‚Äù to vary
We say we have \(n-1\) degrees of freedom

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Bernoulli Population

Setup:

Population: \(X \sim Bernoulli(p)\) where

\(P(X=1) = p\) (success)
\(P(X=0) = 1-p = q\) (failure)

Parameters: \(E[X] = p\) and \(V[X] = p(1-p) = pq\)
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Sample Proportion
The sample proportion is just the sample mean for a Bernoulli population:
\[\hat{p} = \bar{X} = \frac{X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n}{n} = \frac{\text{number of successes}}{n}\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Approximate Distribution (by CLT)
When \(n \to \infty\), the Central Limit Theorem gives us:
\[\bar{X} = \hat{p} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(p, \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}\right)\]
Equivalently:
\[Z_n = \frac{\bar{X} - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)/n}} = \frac{\hat{p} - p}{\sqrt{pq/n}} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N(0, 1)\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Airport Waiting Times
Problem: Waiting time for takeoff at an airport is Normally distributed with mean \(\mu = 4\) minutes. A random sample of \(n = 21\) planes gave \(s' = 1.81\) minutes.
Questions:

What is the sampling distribution of \(\bar{X}\)?
Find \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5)\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Solution (a)
Population: \(X \sim N(\mu = 4, \sigma)\) with \(\sigma\) unknown
Sample: \(n = 21\), \(s' = 1.81\)
Sampling distribution:
\[T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{s'/\sqrt{n}} = \frac{\bar{X} - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}} \sim t_{20}\]
Therefore:
\[\bar{X} \sim t_{20} \text{ distribution centered at } \mu = 4 \text{ with scale } s'/\sqrt{21}\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Solution (b)
Find \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5)\):
\[P(\bar{X} > 4.5) = P\left(\frac{\bar{X} - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}} > \frac{4.5 - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}}\right)\]
\[= P(T > 1.266) = P(T_{20} > 1.266)\]
From t-table with 20 degrees of freedom:

\(t_{0.10, 20} = 1.325\), so \(P(T > 1.325) = 0.10\)
Since \(1.266 < 1.325\), we have \(P(T > 1.266) > 0.10\)

Approximate answer: \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5) \approx 0.11\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Client Accounts
Problem: A company wants to validate client account values (in euros). Accounts follow \(N(\mu = 385, \sigma = ?)\). A sample of \(n\) accounts gives \(s' = 122.6\) euros.
Question: Find \(n\) such that the sample mean does not deviate from the population mean by more than 20 euros in 90% of cases. (Assume \(n > 30\))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Solution
Since \(n > 30\), we can use the Normal approximation:
\[\bar{X} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(385, \frac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\]
We want: \(P(|\bar{X} - 385| < 20) = 0.90\)
This is equivalent to: \(P(|\bar{X} - 385| > 20) = 0.10\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Solution (Continued)
\[P\left(\left|\frac{\bar{X} - 385}{122.6/\sqrt{n}}\right| > \frac{20}{122.6/\sqrt{n}}\right) = 0.10\]
\[P\left(|Z| > \frac{20\sqrt{n}}{122.6}\right) = 0.10\]
From Normal table: \(P(|Z| > 1.645) = 0.10\)
Therefore:
\[\frac{20\sqrt{n}}{122.6} = 1.645\]
\[\sqrt{n} = \frac{1.645 \times 122.6}{20} = 10.084\]
\[n \approx 102\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: TV Cable Subscription
Problem: A cable TV channel is subscribed by 10% of residents (\(p = 0.10\)). A marketing company surveys \(n = 100\) random residents.
Question: Advertising contracts will only be renewed if the sample proportion exceeds 8.5%. What‚Äôs the probability this occurs?

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: Solution
Population: \(X \sim Bernoulli(p = 0.10)\)
Sample: \(n = 100\)
Check CLT conditions: \(np = 10 \geq 5\) and \(n(1-p) = 90 \geq 5\) ‚úì
Sampling distribution:
\[\hat{p} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(0.10, \sqrt{\frac{0.10 \times 0.90}{100}}\right) = N(0.10, 0.03)\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: Solution (Continued)
Find \(P(\hat{p} > 0.085)\):
\[P(\hat{p} > 0.085) = P\left(\frac{\hat{p} - 0.10}{0.03} > \frac{0.085 - 0.10}{0.03}\right)\]
\[= P(Z > -0.50) = P(Z < 0.50)\]
From Normal table: \(P(Z < 0.50) = 0.6915\)
Answer: The probability of renewing the contract is approximately 69.15%.

Summary: Sampling Distributions
What We Learned:

Statistics are functions of sample data with no unknown parameters
t-Student distribution is used when \(\sigma\) is unknown (Normal population)
Chi-square distribution describes the sampling distribution of variance
Central Limit Theorem allows us to use Normal approximation for large samples
Sample proportions from Bernoulli populations are approximately Normal (large \(n\))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Practical Guidelines
Choosing the Right Distribution:

Small sample, Normal pop., \(\sigma\) unknown ‚Üí Use \(t_{n-1}\)
Large sample (\(n > 30\)) ‚Üí Use \(N(0,1)\) (CLT)
Variance problems, Normal pop. ‚Üí Use \(\chi^2_{n-1}\)
Proportions, large sample ‚Üí Use \(N(0,1)\) (CLT)







Important


Always check assumptions before applying these results!

The t-Student Distribution



Definition


A continuous random variable \(T\) follows a t-Student distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom if its probability density function is:
\[f(t) = \frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{\nu+1}{2}\right)}{\sqrt{\nu\pi}\,\Gamma\left(\frac{\nu}{2}\right)} \left(1 + \frac{t^2}{\nu}\right)^{-\frac{\nu+1}{2}}, \quad t \in \mathbb{R}\]
Notation: \(T \sim t_\nu\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Properties of t-Student
Key Properties:

Symmetric around zero: \(E(T) = 0\) (for \(\nu > 1\))
Variance: \(Var(T) = \frac{\nu}{\nu - 2}\) (for \(\nu > 2\))
As \(\nu \to \infty\): \(t_\nu \to N(0,1)\)
Heavier tails than the standard normal distribution
Shape depends on degrees of freedom \(\nu\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
t-Student vs.¬†Normal Distribution

As degrees of freedom increase, the t-distribution converges to the standard Normal distribution.

For a t-Student distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom:

Tables typically provide: \(P(T > t_{\alpha, \nu}) = \alpha\)
Due to symmetry: \(t_{1-\alpha, \nu} = -t_{\alpha, \nu}\)

Example: For \(\nu = 10\) and \(\alpha = 0.05\):

\(t_{0.05, 10} = 1.812\)
This means: \(P(T > 1.812) = 0.05\)
By symmetry: \(P(T < -1.812) = 0.05\)

The Chi-square Distribution



Definition


A continuous random variable \(Q\) follows a chi-square distribution with \(\nu\) degrees of freedom if:
\[f(q) = \frac{1}{2^{\nu/2}\Gamma(\nu/2)} q^{(\nu/2)-1} e^{-q/2}, \quad q > 0\]
Notation: \(Q \sim \chi^2_\nu\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Properties of Chi-square
Key Properties:

\(E(Q) = \nu\) (mean equals degrees of freedom)
\(Var(Q) = 2\nu\)
Right-skewed distribution (not symmetric)
Only positive values
Sum property: If \(Q_1 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_1}\) and \(Q_2 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_2}\) are independent, then \(Q_1 + Q_2 \sim \chi^2_{\nu_1 + \nu_2}\)

text:
Sampling Distribution of Variance
Result:
\[Q = \frac{(n-1)S'^2}{\sigma^2} = \frac{nS^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{n-1}\]






Note



The chi-square distribution has \(n-1\) degrees of freedom
We lose one degree of freedom because we estimate \(\mu\) with \(\bar{X}\)
This result is only exact for Normal populations

title: Sampling Distributions
section: Why Do We Lose a Degree of Freedom?
text:
Why Do We Lose a Degree of Freedom?
When calculating \(S^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2\):

We have \(n\) observations: \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\)
But we use \(\bar{X}\) (calculated from the data) instead of \(\mu\)
The \(n\) deviations \((X_i - \bar{X})\) must sum to zero
Therefore, only \(n-1\) of them are ‚Äúfree‚Äù to vary
We say we have \(n-1\) degrees of freedom

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Bernoulli Population

Setup:

Population: \(X \sim Bernoulli(p)\) where

\(P(X=1) = p\) (success)
\(P(X=0) = 1-p = q\) (failure)

Parameters: \(E(X) = p\) and \(Var(X) = p(1-p) = pq\)
Random sample: \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Sample Proportion
The sample proportion is just the sample mean for a Bernoulli population:
\[\hat{p} = \bar{X} = \frac{X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n}{n} = \frac{\text{number of successes}}{n}\]
Expected Value and Variance:
\[E(\bar{X}) = E(\hat{p}) = p\]
\[Var(\bar{X}) = Var(\hat{p}) = \frac{p(1-p)}{n} = \frac{pq}{n}\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Approximate Distribution (by CLT)
When \(n \to \infty\), the Central Limit Theorem gives us:
\[\bar{X} = \hat{p} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(p, \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}\right)\]
Equivalently:
\[Z_n = \frac{\bar{X} - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)/n}} = \frac{\hat{p} - p}{\sqrt{pq/n}} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N(0, 1)\]
Rule of thumb: This approximation works well when \(np \geq 5\) and \(n(1-p) \geq 5\).

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Airport Waiting Times
Problem: Waiting time for takeoff at an airport is Normally distributed with mean \(\mu = 4\) minutes. A random sample of \(n = 21\) planes gave \(s' = 1.81\) minutes.
Questions:

What is the sampling distribution of \(\bar{X}\)?
Find \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5)\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Solution (a)
Population: \(X \sim N(\mu = 4, \sigma)\) with \(\sigma\) unknown
Sample: \(n = 21\), \(s' = 1.81\)
Sampling distribution:
\[T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{s'/\sqrt{n}} = \frac{\bar{X} - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}} \sim t_{20}\]
Therefore:
\[\bar{X} \sim t_{20} \text{ distribution centered at } \mu = 4 \text{ with scale } s'/\sqrt{21}\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 1: Solution (b)
Find \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5)\):
\[P(\bar{X} > 4.5) = P\left(\frac{\bar{X} - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}} > \frac{4.5 - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}}\right)\]
\[= P(T > 1.266) = P(T_{20} > 1.266)\]
From t-table with 20 degrees of freedom:

\(t_{0.10, 20} = 1.325\), so \(P(T > 1.325) = 0.10\)
Since \(1.266 < 1.325\), we have \(P(T > 1.266) > 0.10\)

Approximate answer: \(P(\bar{X} > 4.5) \approx 0.11\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Client Accounts
Problem: A company wants to validate client account values (in euros). Accounts follow \(N(\mu = 385, \sigma = ?)\). A sample of \(n\) accounts gives \(s' = 122.6\) euros.
Question: Find \(n\) such that the sample mean does not deviate from the population mean by more than 20 euros in 90% of cases. (Assume \(n > 30\))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Solution
Since \(n > 30\), we can use the Normal approximation:
\[\bar{X} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(385, \frac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\]
We want: \(P(|\bar{X} - 385| < 20) = 0.90\)
This is equivalent to: \(P(|\bar{X} - 385| > 20) = 0.10\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 2: Solution (Continued)
\[P\left(\left|\frac{\bar{X} - 385}{122.6/\sqrt{n}}\right| > \frac{20}{122.6/\sqrt{n}}\right) = 0.10\]
\[P\left(|Z| > \frac{20\sqrt{n}}{122.6}\right) = 0.10\]
From Normal table: \(P(|Z| > 1.645) = 0.10\)
Therefore:
\[\frac{20\sqrt{n}}{122.6} = 1.645\]
\[\sqrt{n} = \frac{1.645 \times 122.6}{20} = 10.084\]
\[n \approx 102\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: TV Cable Subscription
Problem: A cable TV channel is subscribed by 10% of residents (\(p = 0.10\)). A marketing company surveys \(n = 100\) random residents.
Question: Advertising contracts will only be renewed if the sample proportion exceeds 8.5%. What‚Äôs the probability this occurs?

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: Solution
Population: \(X \sim Bernoulli(p = 0.10)\)
Sample: \(n = 100\)
Check CLT conditions: \(np = 10 \geq 5\) and \(n(1-p) = 90 \geq 5\) ‚úì
Sampling distribution:
\[\hat{p} \overset{CLT}{\sim} N\left(0.10, \sqrt{\frac{0.10 \times 0.90}{100}}\right) = N(0.10, 0.03)\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Example 3: Solution (Continued)
Find \(P(\hat{p} > 0.085)\):
\[P(\hat{p} > 0.085) = P\left(\frac{\hat{p} - 0.10}{0.03} > \frac{0.085 - 0.10}{0.03}\right)\]
\[= P(Z > -0.50) = P(Z < 0.50)\]
From Normal table: \(P(Z < 0.50) = 0.6915\)
Answer: The probability of renewing the contract is approximately 69.15%.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Summary: Sampling Distributions
What We Learned:

Statistics are functions of sample data with no unknown parameters
t-Student distribution is used when \(\sigma\) is unknown (Normal population)
Chi-square distribution describes the sampling distribution of variance
Central Limit Theorem allows us to use Normal approximation for large samples
Sample proportions from Bernoulli populations are approximately Normal (large \(n\))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Practical Guidelines
Choosing the Right Distribution:

Small sample, Normal pop., \(\sigma\) unknown ‚Üí Use \(t_{n-1}\)
Large sample (\(n > 30\)) ‚Üí Use \(N(0,1)\) (CLT)
Variance problems, Normal pop. ‚Üí Use \(\chi^2_{n-1}\)
Proportions, large sample ‚Üí Use \(N(0,1)\) (CLT)







Important


Always check assumptions before applying these results!

title: Chapter I - Statistics II - Exercises
text:
Questions

The Concept of a Statistic

Question 1

Consider \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)\), \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), a random sample from a population \(X \sim \text{Normal}(\mu = -2,\; \sigma)\), where \(\sigma\) is unknown. Determine whether the following random variables are not statistics:

TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \bar{X}\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \dfrac{\bar{X}}{\sigma}\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \dfrac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}}\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \mu)^2}{n}\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n} = S^2\)
TRUEFALSE \(T(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n) = \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i - \bar{X})^2}{n-1} = S'^2\)



Hint

Recall that a statistic is a function of the sample values that does not involve any unknown parameters. Here, \(\mu = -2\) is known but \(\sigma\) is unknown.

Items (a), (b), (f), and (g) depend only on \(X_i\) and \(\bar{X}\) (and known constants like \(n\)), so they are statistics ‚Äî hence the statement that they are ‚Äúnot statistics‚Äù is False.
Items (c), (d), and (e) involve the unknown parameter \(\sigma\) or \(\mu\) (note: although \(\mu=-2\) is given, items (d) and (e) include \(\sigma\) as well, and (c) directly uses \(\sigma\)), so they are not statistics ‚Äî the statement is True.

Correction on (d) and (e): Even though \(\mu=-2\) is known, (d) involves \(\sigma\) (unknown) in the denominator and (e) involves \(\mu\) which, while numerically known here, in items (d) the presence of \(\sigma\) makes it fail. For (e): since \(\mu\) is known, this would actually be a statistic if all parameters involved were known. However, note the formulation carefully: (d) includes \(\sigma\) explicitly ‚Üí not a statistic. (e) includes \(\mu\) (which is known = \(-2\)) so actually is a statistic. Let us re-examine:
Actually, since \(\mu = -2\) is known:


involves \(\sigma\) (unknown) ‚Üí not a statistic ‚Üí True ‚úì

involves \(\mu\) (known) but not \(\sigma\) ‚Üí it is a statistic ‚Üí False


Let us reconsider (e) with additional context. In the original exercise, (e) is defined as \(T = \frac{\sum(X_i - \mu)^2}{n}\), and a separate item (f) from the original list includes \(\frac{\sum\left(\frac{X_i - \mu}{\sigma}\right)^2}{}\). The resolution confirms: (c), (d), and (f-original) are not statistics because they involve \(\sigma\).





Sampling Distribution of the Mean

Question 2 (Normal population, \(\sigma\) unknown ‚Üí t-Student)

Suppose the waiting time on the runway for takeoff at a certain airport is a random variable modelled by a Normal distribution with a mean of 4 minutes. A random sample of 21 aircraft was selected, yielding a corrected sample standard deviation \(s' = 1.81\) min.
TRUEFALSE The probability that the sample mean waiting time exceeds 5 minutes is equal to 0.010.


Solution

Population: \(X \sim \text{Normal}(\mu = 4,\; \sigma = ?)\) (standard deviation unknown)
Sample: \(n = 21 < 30\); \(s' = 1.81\) min.
Since the population is Normal and \(\sigma\) is unknown, the sampling distribution of the mean is:
\[T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{S'/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{(20)}\]
\[P(\bar{X} > 5) = P\!\left(T > \frac{5 - 4}{1.81/\sqrt{21}}\right) = P(T > 2.53) = 0.010\]
The statement is True.




Question 3 (Unknown population, \(\sigma\) known ‚Üí CLT)

At a financial firm, the profit generated by each investment made in the last year has a mean of ‚Ç¨8,200 and a standard deviation of ‚Ç¨3,600. Consider a random sample of 100 investments.
The probability that the sample mean differs from the population mean by more than ‚Ç¨806.76 is equal to:
0.01250.0250.9875None of the above


Solution

Population: \(L \to\) profit (unknown distribution); \(\mu = 8{,}200\)‚Ç¨; \(\sigma = 3{,}600\)‚Ç¨ (known).
Sample: \(n = 100 > 30\).
By the CLT: \[\bar{X} \;\dot{\sim}\; N\!\left(\mu,\; \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right) \equiv N(8200,\; 360)\]
\[P(|\bar{X} - \mu| > 806.76) = P\!\left(|Z| > \frac{806.76}{360}\right) \approx P(|Z| > 2.241)\]
\[= 2 - 2\Phi(2.241) = 2 - 2 \times 0.9875 = 0.025\]
The correct option is b) 0.025.




Question 4 (Normal population, \(\sigma\) unknown, \(n > 30\) ‚Üí Normal approx.)

A company wishes to validate the value (in euros) of its accounts receivable, which follow a Normal distribution with mean \(\mu = 385\) and unknown standard deviation. A random sample of \(n\) independent client accounts yields a corrected sample standard deviation \(s' = 122.6\) euros.
TRUEFALSE The sample size needed (assuming \(s'\) remains unchanged) so that the sample mean does not deviate from the population mean by more than 20 euros in 90% of cases is \(n = 102\). (Assume, for calculations, that the value of \(n\) will be greater than 30.)


Solution

Population: \(X \sim N(\mu = 385,\; \sigma = ?)\)
Sample: \(n > 30\); \(s' = 122.6\)
By the CLT (since \(n > 30\) and \(\sigma\) unknown): \[\bar{X} \;\dot{\sim}\; N\!\left(\mu,\; \frac{s'}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\]
We want: \[P(|\bar{X} - \mu| < 20) = 0.9 \iff P\!\left(|Z| < \frac{20}{122.6/\sqrt{n}}\right) = 0.9\] \[\iff \frac{20}{122.6/\sqrt{n}} = 1.645 \iff \sqrt{n} = \frac{1.645 \times 122.6}{20}\] \[\iff n \geq \left(\frac{1.645 \times 122.6}{20}\right)^2 \approx 102\]
The statement is True.





Sampling Distribution of the Proportion

Question 5 (Bernoulli population ‚Üí CLT)

Suppose a certain cable TV channel is subscribed to by 10% of the residents of a country. Since this channel has been operating for a very short time, a marketing firm decided to estimate this proportion based on a random sample of 100 residents before renewing its advertising contracts with the channel.
TRUEFALSE Given that contracts will only be renewed if the sample proportion exceeds 8.5%, the approximate probability of this occurring is 0.6915.


Solution

Population: \(X \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p = 0.1)\)
Sample: \(n = 100 > 30\) (CLT applies)
\[\hat{p} = \bar{X} \;\dot{\sim}\; N\!\left(p,\; \sqrt{\frac{pq}{n}}\right) = N\!\left(0.1,\; \sqrt{\frac{0.1 \times 0.9}{100}}\right) = N(0.1,\; 0.03)\]
\[P(\hat{p} > 0.085) \approx P\!\left(Z > \frac{0.085 - 0.1}{0.03}\right) = P(Z > -0.5) = \Phi(0.5) = 0.6915\]
The statement is True.





Sampling Distribution of the Variance

Question 6 (Normal population, Chi-Squared)

Suppose we wish to analyse the viability of a project whose key element is the price (in monetary units, m.u.) of the raw material, well modelled by a random variable \(X \sim N(\mu,\; \sigma)\).
A random sample \((X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_{16})\) was selected, yielding a corrected sample variance \(s'^2 = 0.18\;\text{m.u.}^2\).

TRUEFALSE \(Q = \dfrac{15\,S'^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{(16)}\)
TRUEFALSE \(P(S'^2 > 1.2163\,\sigma^2) = 0.25\)



Solution

Population: \(X \sim N(\mu,\; \sigma)\)
Sample: \(n = 16\); \(s'^2 = 0.18\)
The pivot quantity is: \[Q = \frac{(n-1)S'^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{(n-1)}\]
So: \[Q = \frac{15\,S'^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{(\mathbf{15})}\]
a) The statement claims \(Q \sim \chi^2_{(16)}\), but the correct degrees of freedom are \(n - 1 = 15\). The statement is False.
b) \[P(S'^2 > 1.2163\,\sigma^2) = P\!\left(\frac{S'^2}{\sigma^2} > 1.2163\right) = P(Q > 15 \times 1.2163) = P(Q > 18.245)\]
Reading directly from the \(\chi^2\) table with 15 degrees of freedom: \(P(Q > 18.245) = 0.25\).
The statement is True.

Important Concepts



Statistical Inference


Statistical inference is the use of a set of methods that allows to draw conclusions about a population, from a random sample of that population.

title: Sampling Distributions

Parameters and Statistics



Estimate


An estimate for a parameter is the realized value of a statistic, i.e., the value you obtain from aplying the function statistic to a particular sample.



Given that the sample is random, because it is a collection of realized random variables, the statistic is itself a random variable. Every time you draw a new sample, you obtain a different estimate.

Normal distribution, \(X\sim Normal(\mu,\sigma^2)\)
It can be standardized \(Z=\frac{X-\mu}{\sigma}\sim Normal(0,1)\)
Given this, from now on, we will focus on the standard normal.

Working with the Normal distribution
Suppose you have a random sample \(\{X_i\}_{i=1}^n\). Then we just saw the average is going to be:
\[\bar{X}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n X_i}{n}\]
And we saw that \(E[\bar{X}]=\mu\), and \(V[\bar{X}]=\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\). This second result is beautiful. Note that we did not make any assumptions on the distribution of \(X\); if we gather a large sample, its average will be close to the true mean with higher probability.

A question

How could we obtain the distribution, using a random sample, for a statistic or a random variable?


To answer this, we need to introduce two new distributions (not covered in Statistics I)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
\(\chi^2\) distribution
Let \(Z_1,Z_2,\dots, Z_n\) random variables iid distributed \(Z_i\sim N(0,1)\).
\[Y=\sum_{i=1}^n Z_i^2=\sum_{i=1}^n\left(\frac{X_i-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2\]
is a random variable distributed \(\chi^2_{\nu}\), where \(\nu\) represents the degrees of freedom.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Degrees of Freedom



Definition


The number of independent values that are free to vary in your data without breaking any constraints.



Formula: \(dof = N - P\)

\(N\) = sample size

\(P\) = number of parameters estimated

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
The Intuitive Example
Imagine you have 4 numbers that must average to 20.

First person picks: 15 ‚úì (free to choose)
Second person picks: 30 ‚úì (free to choose)

Third person picks: 10 ‚úì (free to choose)
Fourth person picks: ? ‚úó (not free!)

The fourth number must be 25 to keep the average at 20.
Result: 3 degrees of freedom (\(df = 4 - 1 = 3\))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Why Degrees of Freedom Matter
In Practice:

‚úì More \(df\) ‚Üí More reliable estimates

‚úì Affects the shape of distributions (\(t\), \(\chi^2\), \(F\))

Key Insight:
When you estimate a parameter (like the mean), you ‚Äúspend‚Äù one degree of freedom. It‚Äôs the cost of using your data to calculate statistics.

Statistical Power


Statistical Power is the probability that your test will detect an effect when there actually is one.
Formula: \(Power = 1 - \beta\) (where \(\beta\) is Type II error rate)
In plain terms: The ability of your study to find a real difference if it exists.

Sampling Distribution:
By the additivity theorem for Normal distributions:
\[\bar{X} \sim N\left(\mu, \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right) \Leftrightarrow Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \sim N(0, 1)\]

text:

Sampling Distribution:
We must use the sample standard deviation:
\[T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{S/\sqrt{n-1}} = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{S'/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{n-1}\]
where \(S' = \sqrt{\frac{n}{n-1}}S\) is the corrected sample standard deviation.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:

Thus:
\[S^2=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i-\bar{X})^2\] and
\[S'^2=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i-\bar{X})^2=\frac{n}{n-1}S^2\]

text:

If we have a large enough sample (larger than 30), we can, from the sample, approximate the distribution of \(\mu\), using the TLC (again, forthcoming):
\[Z=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\frac{S}{\sqrt{n-1}}}=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\frac{S'}{\sqrt{n}}}\overset{\cdot}{\sim}N(0,1)\]

For \(n\) sufficiently large (\(n \geq 30\)), by the Central Limit Theorem:
\[Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \underbrace{\overset{\cdot}{\sim}}_{CLT} N(0, 1)\]

Exercise 8
A pharmaceutical company produces tablets in which the variability of the amount of active substance from one tablet to another must be very small. The population standard deviation is supposedly one milligram. Inspectors from the Ministry of Health selected a random sample of 16 tablets.
Assuming the population is Normal, the probability that the corrected sample variance exceeds \(0.736\;\text{mg}^2\) is:
¬†
a) 0.76 ‚ÄÉ b) 0.25 ‚ÄÉ c) 0.75 ‚ÄÉ d) none of the above

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Exercise 8 ‚Äî Solution
Population: \(X \sim N(\mu,\; \sigma)\), with \(\sigma = 1\) (i.e.¬†\(\sigma^2 = 1\))
Sample: \(n = 16\)
Pivot quantity:
\[
Q = \frac{(n-1)\,S'^2}{\sigma^2} = \frac{15\,S'^2}{1} = 15\,S'^2 \sim \chi^2_{(n-1)} \equiv \chi^2_{(15)}
\]
We want:
\[
P(S'^2 > 0.736) = P(Q > 15 \times 0.736) = P(Q > 11.04)
\]
Reading directly from the \(\chi^2\) table with 15 degrees of freedom:
\[
P(Q > 11.04) \approx 0.75
\]
The correct answer is c).

Exercise 7
A company wishes to validate the value (in euros) of its accounts receivable from clients, assuming the underlying distribution of account values is \(\text{Normal}(\mu = 385,\; \sigma = ?)\).
A random sample of 25 client accounts (independent) was selected, yielding a corrected sample standard deviation \(s' = 122.6\) euros.

a) \(\boxed{V}\) \(\boxed{F}\) The sampling distribution of the mean value of client accounts is \(t_{(25)}\).
b) \(\boxed{V}\) \(\boxed{F}\) The required sample size (assuming the corrected sample standard deviation remains the same) so that the sample mean does not deviate from the population mean by more than 20 euros in 90% of cases is \(n = 102\). (Assume that the value of \(n\) to be found will be greater than 30.)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Exercise 7 ‚Äî Solution a)
Population: \(X \sim N(\mu = 385,\; \sigma = ?)\) (standard deviation unknown)
Sample: \(n = 25\); \(s' = 122.6\)
¬†
The sampling distribution of the sample mean (mean value of client accounts) is given by:
\[
T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\dfrac{S'}{\sqrt{n}}} \sim t_{(n-1)} \equiv t_{(24)}
\]
The statement claims \(t_{(25)}\), but the correct distribution is \(t_{(24)}\).
The statement is False.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Exercise 7 ‚Äî Solution b)
Population: \(X \sim N(\mu = 385,\; \sigma = ?)\) | Sample: \(n \geq 30\); \(s' = 122.6\)
Since \(n \geq 30\), by the CLT:
\[
\bar{X} \;\underset{\text{approx. by CLT}}{\sim}\; N\!\left(\mu,\; \frac{s'}{\sqrt{n}}\right) \equiv N\!\left(385,\; \frac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}\right)
\]
We want \(P(|\bar{X} - \mu| < 20) = 0.9\):
\[
P\!\left(|Z| < \frac{20}{\dfrac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}}\right) = 0.9 \;\Leftrightarrow\; P\!\left(|Z| > \frac{20}{\dfrac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}}\right) = 0.1
\]
\[
\Leftrightarrow\; \frac{20}{\dfrac{122.6}{\sqrt{n}}} = 1.645 \;\Leftrightarrow\; n \geq 102
\]
The statement is True.

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
First case
Let \(Y=\sum_{i=1}^n X_i\), the total amount of successes. Then \(Y\) has a sample distribution:
\[Y=\sum_{i=1}^m\sim Binomial(n,p)\]
If \(n\) is large enough, we can apply the \(CLT\) to get an approximate sample distribution: \[Y\overset{\cdot}{\sim} N\left(np,\sqrt{np(1-p)}\right)\Leftrightarrow Z_n=\frac{Y-np}{\sqrt{np(1-p)}}\overset{\cdot}{\sim}N(0,1)\]

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Second case
Let the statistic \(\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i = \frac{Y}{n}\) the proportion of successess that, in a sample of size \(n\), have some characteristic.
It is of interest to know the sampling distribution of \(\bar{X}=\hat{p}\)
Expected Value and Variance:
\[E[\bar{X}] = E[\hat{p}] = p\]
\[V[\bar{X}] = V[\hat{p}] = \frac{p(1-p)}{n} = \frac{pq}{n}\]

&= P(Z \geq -2.56) = P(Z \leq 2.56) = \Phi(2.56) = 0.9948

\]

Continuity correction

text:
Exercise 10 ‚Äî Solution b)
b) From the interviews conducted, \(X\) residents out of \(n\) stated they would use Sweet Drop, thus the sample proportion is \(\dfrac{X}{n}\).
\[
